markdownRemark.html:
In the last post, we deal with the rotations in quantum mechanics. In the post, we focus on yet another translation, not in space, but in time. From time-evolution of quantum mechanical states, we will meet the Schrödinger equation and the Hamiltonian, the operator corresponding to the total energy of the system.

  • The Time-Evolution Operator and the Schrödinger Equation
  • The Hamiltonian
  • Time Dependence of Expectation
  • Precession of Spin-1/2 Particles in a B-field
  • Energy-Time Uncertainty
  • References

The Time-Evolution Operator and the Schrödinger Equation

Consider a time-dependent state ∣ψ(t)⟩|\psi(t)\rangle∣ψ(t)⟩, we’d like a time-dependent operator U^(t)\hat U(t)U^(t), such that:

U^(t)∣ψ(0)⟩=∣ψ(t)⟩\hat U (t) |\psi(0)\rangle = |\psi(t)\rangleU^(t)∣ψ(0)⟩=∣ψ(t)⟩

What properties should this time-evolution operator have? It turns out it should be very similar to a rotational operator R^(dψ)\hat R(d\psi)R^(dψ):

  1. It should act like the identity operator when t=0t=0t=0: U^(t=0)=1\hat U(t = 0) = \mathbf 1U^(t=0)=1
  2. It should be dimensionless.

  3. It should be unitary, a.k.a norm-preserving, i.e.

    ⟨ψ(t)∣ψ(t)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣U^†(t)U^(t)∣ψ(0)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣ψ(0)⟩⟺U†(t)U^=1\langle\psi(t)|\psi(t)\rangle = \langle\psi(0)|\hat U^\dagger (t) \hat U (t)|\psi(0)\rangle = \langle\psi(0)|\psi(0)\rangle \Longleftrightarrow U^\dagger (t) \hat U = \pmb 1⟨ψ(t)∣ψ(t)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣U^†(t)U^(t)∣ψ(0)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣ψ(0)⟩⟺U†(t)U^=11

It should be reasonable to motivate that the time-evolution operator have a similar form as the rotational operator. And just like the rotational operator has a generator of rotation, spin operator, the time-evolution operator also has its generator. We assert that—and it will be apparent that this is equivalent to the 5th postulate, the time-dependent Schrödinger equation—that:

U^(dt)=1−iℏH^dt\hat U(dt) = 1 - \frac{i}{\hbar} \hat H dtU^(dt)=1−ℏi​H^dt

where H^\hat HH^ is called the Hamiltonian, the generator of time translation.

Now just like what we did for the rotational operator in the second post, we can obtain a closed form solution for the time-evolution operator by taking a series of infinitesimal time translations. Assuming the Hamiltonian is time-independent:

U^(t)=lim⁡N→∞(1−iℏH^tN)N=e−iH^t/ℏ\hat U(t) = \lim_{N \to\infty} (1 - \frac{i}{\hbar} \hat H \frac{t}{N})^N = e^{-i\hat H t/\hbar}U^(t)=N→∞lim​(1−ℏi​H^Nt​)N=e−iH^t/ℏ

The time-evolution operator also satisfies a first-order differential equation w.r.t time:

U^(t+dt)=U^(dt)U^(t)=(1−iℏH^dt)U^(t)\hat U(t+dt) = \hat U(dt) \hat U(t) = (1-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat H dt) \hat U(t)U^(t+dt)=U^(dt)U^(t)=(1−ℏi​H^dt)U^(t)

Then,

U^(t+dt)−U^(t)=−(iℏH^dt)U^(t)\hat U(t+dt) -\hat U(t) = -(\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat H dt) \hat U(t)U^(t+dt)−U^(t)=−(ℏi​H^dt)U^(t)

And take the infinitesimal limit on time,

iℏddtU^=H^U^(t)i\hbar \frac{d}{dt}\hat U = \hat H \hat U(t)iℏdtd​U^=H^U^(t)

Finally, apply the operator equation on the initial state ∣ψ(0)⟩|\psi(0)\rangle∣ψ(0)⟩:

iℏddt∣ψ(t)⟩=H^∣ψ(t)⟩i\hbar \frac{d}{dt} |\psi(t)\rangle = \hat H |\psi(t)\rangleiℏdtd​∣ψ(t)⟩=H^∣ψ(t)⟩

There we have the time-dependent Schrödinger equation.

The Hamiltonian

Let’s come back to the generator of time translation, the Hamiltonian. Like the generator of rotation, the Hamiltonian is a Hermitian operator. It’s reasonable to postulate that it corresponds to some measurable quantity. Let’s first consider its unit, [H^]=[ℏ/t][\hat H] = [\hbar/t][H^]=[ℏ/t], which is the unit of energy. Moreover, assuming Hamiltonian is time-independent, its expectation value is time independent.

To see this, we first Taylor-expand the time-evolution operator:

U^(t)=e−iH^t/ℏ=1−iH^tℏ+12!(−iH^tℏ)2+⋯\hat U(t) = e^{-i\hat H t/\hbar} = 1 - \frac{i\hat H t}{\hbar} + \frac{1}{2!}(-\frac{i\hat H t}{\hbar})^2 + \cdotsU^(t)=e−iH^t/ℏ=1−ℏiH^t​+2!1​(−ℏiH^t​)2+⋯

The expansion shows that H^\hat HH^ commutes with U^\hat UU^, since U^\hat UU^ is the sum of powers of H^\hat HH^. Therefore,

⟨ψ(t)∣H^∣ψ(t)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣U^†H^U^∣ψ(0)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣U^†U^H^∣ψ(0)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣H^∣ψ(0)⟩\langle\psi(t)|\hat H | \psi(t)\rangle = \langle\psi(0)|\hat U^\dagger \hat H \hat U| \psi(0)\rangle = \langle\psi(0)|\hat U^\dagger \hat U \hat H | \psi(0)\rangle = \langle\psi(0)|\hat H | \psi(0)\rangle⟨ψ(t)∣H^∣ψ(t)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣U^†H^U^∣ψ(0)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣U^†U^H^∣ψ(0)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣H^∣ψ(0)⟩

These results suggest, with our classical intuition, the Hamiltonian is the energy operator. The eigenstates of the Hamiltonian is the energy eigenstates ∣E⟩|E\rangle∣E⟩, and the eigenvalues are measurable energy EEE of the system:

H^∣E⟩=E∣E⟩\hat H |E\rangle = E |E\rangleH^∣E⟩=E∣E⟩

The time-evolution of an energy eigenstate is especially convenient. Again, we use the Taylor-expansion of the time-evolution operator,

U^(t)∣E⟩=e−iH^t/ℏ∣E⟩=[1−iH^tℏ+12!(−iH^tℏ)2+⋯]∣E⟩=[1−iEtℏ+12!(−iEtℏ)2+⋯]∣E⟩=e−iEt/ℏ\begin{aligned} \hat U(t) |E\rangle &= e^{-i\hat H t/\hbar} |E\rangle \\ &= \Big[1 - \frac{i\hat H t}{\hbar} + \frac{1}{2!}(-\frac{i\hat H t}{\hbar})^2 + \cdots \Big] |E\rangle \\ &= \Big[1 - \frac{iE t}{\hbar} + \frac{1}{2!}(-\frac{iE t}{\hbar})^2 + \cdots \Big] |E\rangle \\ &= e^{-i E t/\hbar} \end{aligned}U^(t)∣E⟩​=e−iH^t/ℏ∣E⟩=[1−ℏiH^t​+2!1​(−ℏiH^t​)2+⋯]∣E⟩=[1−ℏiEt​+2!1​(−ℏiEt​)2+⋯]∣E⟩=e−iEt/ℏ​

Time Dependence of Expectation

With the Schrödinger equation, we can also find the expectation of a measurement.

ddt⟨A⟩=ddt⟨ψ(t)∣A^∣ψ(t)⟩=(ddt⟨ψ(t)∣A^∣ψ(t)⟩)+⟨ψ(t)∣A^(ddt∣ψ(t)⟩)+⟨ψ(t)∣∂A^∂t∣ψ(t)⟩=(1−iℏ⟨ψ(t)∣H^)A^∣ψ(t)⟩)+⟨ψ(t)∣A^(1iℏH^∣ψ(t)⟩)+⟨ψ(t)∣∂A^∂t∣ψ(t)⟩=iℏ⟨ψ(t)∣[H^,A^]∣ψ(t)⟩+⟨ψ(t)∣∂A^∂t∣ψ(t)⟩\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dt} \langle A\rangle &= \frac{d}{dt}\langle\psi(t)| \hat A |\psi(t)\rangle \\ &= \Big(\frac{d}{dt}\langle\psi(t)| \hat A |\psi(t)\rangle\Big) + \langle\psi(t)| \hat A \Big(\frac{d}{dt}|\psi(t)\rangle\Big) + \langle\psi(t)| \frac{\partial \hat A}{\partial t}|\psi(t)\rangle \\ &= \Big(\frac{1}{-i\hbar}\langle\psi(t)| \hat H) \hat A |\psi(t)\rangle\Big) + \langle\psi(t)| \hat A \Big(\frac{1}{i\hbar}\hat H|\psi(t)\rangle\Big) + \langle\psi(t)| \frac{\partial \hat A}{\partial t}|\psi(t)\rangle \\ &= \frac{i}{\hbar} \langle\psi(t)| \Big[ \hat H, \hat A \Big] |\psi(t)\rangle + \langle\psi(t)| \frac{\partial \hat A}{\partial t}|\psi(t)\rangle \end{aligned}dtd​⟨A⟩​=dtd​⟨ψ(t)∣A^∣ψ(t)⟩=(dtd​⟨ψ(t)∣A^∣ψ(t)⟩)+⟨ψ(t)∣A^(dtd​∣ψ(t)⟩)+⟨ψ(t)∣∂t∂A^​∣ψ(t)⟩=(−iℏ1​⟨ψ(t)∣H^)A^∣ψ(t)⟩)+⟨ψ(t)∣A^(iℏ1​H^∣ψ(t)⟩)+⟨ψ(t)∣∂t∂A^​∣ψ(t)⟩=ℏi​⟨ψ(t)∣[H^,A^]∣ψ(t)⟩+⟨ψ(t)∣∂t∂A^​∣ψ(t)⟩​

where in the second to last step we apply the Schrödinger equation and its adjoint complement −iℏddt⟨ψ(t)∣=⟨ψ(t)∣H^-i\hbar \frac{d}{dt} \langle\psi(t)| = \langle\psi(t)| \hat H−iℏdtd​⟨ψ(t)∣=⟨ψ(t)∣H^.

This relationship tells us that an expectation value can be time-dependent if the operator does not commute with the Hamiltonian or if the operator time-dependent.

Precession of Spin-1/2 Particles in a B-field

Indeed, we will have an example of a time-dependent operator. In fact a time-dependent Hamiltonian, which will result in a time-dependent expectation value for the energy of the system.

Suppose we have a homogeneous magnetic field ±B=B0k^\pm B = B_0 \hat k±B=B0​k^. Assume we have an electron with no kinetic energy in the field. In the classical mechanics, the total energy will be its potential energy,

E=−μ⋅B=−gq2mecS⋅B=ge2mecB0Sz=ω0Sz where ω0=ge2mecE = - \pmb \mu \cdot \pmb B = - \frac{gq}{2m_ec} \pmb S \cdot \pmb B = \frac{ge}{2m_ec} B_0 S_z = \omega_0 S_z \text{ where } \omega_0 = \frac{ge}{2m_ec}E=−μμ⋅BB=−2me​cgq​SS⋅BB=2me​cge​B0​Sz​=ω0​Sz​ where ω0​=2me​cge​

But this is erroneous, since we cannot even comprehend spin S\pmb SSS in the classical mechanics. In the quantum mechanics, we need to express the Hamiltonian with the spin operator:

H^=ω0Sz^\hat H = \omega_0 \hat{S_z}H^=ω0​Sz​^​

The hamiltonian has the same eigenstates as Sz^\hat{S_z}Sz​^​, ∣±z⟩|\pm z\rangle∣±z⟩. The energy eigenvalues can be calculated:

H^∣±z⟩=ω0Sz^∣±z⟩=±ℏω02∣±z⟩=E±∣±z⟩\hat H |\pm z\rangle = \omega_0 \hat{S_z} |\pm z\rangle = \pm \frac{\hbar \omega_0}{2} |\pm z\rangle = E_\pm |\pm z\rangleH^∣±z⟩=ω0​Sz​^​∣±z⟩=±2ℏω0​​∣±z⟩=E±​∣±z⟩

So the energy eigenvalues are E±=±ℏω02E_\pm = \pm \frac{\hbar \omega_0}{2}E±​=±2ℏω0​​ for ∣±z⟩|\pm z\rangle∣±z⟩.

What will happen as time evolves? At time ttt, the time-evolution operator is:

U^(t)=e−iH^t/ℏ=e−iω0Sz^t/ℏ=R^z(ω0t)\hat U(t) = e^{-i\hat H t/\hbar} = e^{-i \omega_0 \hat{S_z} t/\hbar} = \hat R_z(\omega_0 t)U^(t)=e−iH^t/ℏ=e−iω0​Sz​^​t/ℏ=R^z​(ω0​t)

The time-evolution operator is the rotation operator about the z axis! This means that the electron’s spin will precess about the z-axis with the period T=2π/ω0T=2\pi/\omega_0T=2π/ω0​.

For an electron originally in the states ∣+x⟩=12∣+z⟩+12∣−z⟩|+ x\rangle = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} |+ z\rangle + \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} |- z\rangle∣+x⟩=2​1​∣+z⟩+2​1​∣−z⟩, we can calculate the expectation value of SzS_zSz​ at time ttt,

⟨Sz⟩=⟨+x∣U^†(t)Sz^U^(t)∣+x⟩=(12⟨+z∣+12⟨−z∣)eiω0Sz^t/ℏSz^e−iω0Sz^t/ℏ(12∣+z⟩+12∣−z⟩)=12(eiω0t/2⟨+z∣+e−iω0t/2⟨−z∣)Sz^12(e−iω0t/2∣+z⟩+eiω0t/2∣−z⟩)=12(eiω0t/2e−iω0t/2)ℏ2(100−1)(e−iω0t/2eiω0t/2)=ℏ212(1−1)=0\begin{aligned} \langle S_z\rangle &= \langle+x|\hat U^\dagger(t) \hat{S_z} \hat U(t)|+x\rangle \\ &= \Big(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \langle+z|+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \langle-z|\Big) e^{i \omega_0 \hat{S_z} t/\hbar} \hat{S_z} e^{-i \omega_0 \hat{S_z} t/\hbar} \Big( \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} |+ z\rangle + \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} |- z\rangle\Big) \\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \Big( e^{i \omega_0 t/2} \langle+z| + e^{- i \omega_0 t/2} \langle-z| \Big) \hat{S_z} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \Big( e^{-i \omega_0 t/2} |+z\rangle + e^{i \omega_0 t/2} |-z\rangle \Big) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \begin{pmatrix} e^{i \omega_0 t/2} & e^{-i \omega_0 t/2} \end{pmatrix} \frac{\hbar}{2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} e^{-i \omega_0 t/2} \\ e^{i \omega_0 t/2} \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \frac{\hbar}{2} \frac{1}{2} (1 -1) = 0 \end{aligned}⟨Sz​⟩​=⟨+x∣U^†(t)Sz​^​U^(t)∣+x⟩=(2​1​⟨+z∣+2​1​⟨−z∣)eiω0​Sz​^​t/ℏSz​^​e−iω0​Sz​^​t/ℏ(2​1​∣+z⟩+2​1​∣−z⟩)=2​1​(eiω0​t/2⟨+z∣+e−iω0​t/2⟨−z∣)Sz​^​2​1​(e−iω0​t/2∣+z⟩+eiω0​t/2∣−z⟩)=21​(eiω0​t/2​e−iω0​t/2​)2ℏ​(10​0−1​)(e−iω0​t/2eiω0​t/2​)=2ℏ​21​(1−1)=0​

The result is as expected. Intuitively, we can think of the spin precessing about the z-axis in the x-y plane, and the measurement of SzS_zSz​ should be time-independent and 0 in expectation.

Similarly, we can calculate ⟨Sx⟩\langle S_x\rangle⟨Sx​⟩,

⟨Sx⟩=⟨+x∣U^†(t)Sx^U^(t)∣+x⟩=(12⟨+z∣+12⟨−z∣)eiω0Sz^t/ℏSx^e−iω0Sz^t/ℏ(12∣+z⟩+12∣−z⟩)=12(eiω0t/2⟨+z∣+e−iω0t/2⟨−z∣)Sx^12(e−iω0t/2∣+z⟩+eiω0t/2∣−z⟩)=12(eiω0t/2e−iω0t/2)ℏ2(0110)(e−iω0t/2eiω0t/2)=ℏ212(eiω0t+e−iω0t)=ℏ2cos(ω0t)\begin{aligned} \langle S_x\rangle &= \langle+x|\hat U^\dagger(t) \hat{S_x} \hat U(t)|+x\rangle \\ &= \Big(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \langle+z|+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \langle-z|\Big) e^{i \omega_0 \hat{S_z} t/\hbar} \hat{S_x} e^{-i \omega_0 \hat{S_z} t/\hbar} \Big( \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} |+ z\rangle + \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} |- z\rangle\Big) \\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \Big( e^{i \omega_0 t/2} \langle+z| + e^{- i \omega_0 t/2} \langle-z| \Big) \hat{S_x} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \Big( e^{-i \omega_0 t/2} |+z\rangle + e^{i \omega_0 t/2} |-z\rangle \Big) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \begin{pmatrix} e^{i \omega_0 t/2} & e^{-i \omega_0 t/2} \end{pmatrix} \frac{\hbar}{2} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} e^{-i \omega_0 t/2} \\ e^{i \omega_0 t/2} \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \frac{\hbar}{2} \frac{1}{2} ( e^{i \omega_0t} + e^{-i \omega_0t}) = \frac{\hbar}{2} cos(\omega_0 t) \end{aligned}⟨Sx​⟩​=⟨+x∣U^†(t)Sx​^​U^(t)∣+x⟩=(2​1​⟨+z∣+2​1​⟨−z∣)eiω0​Sz​^​t/ℏSx​^​e−iω0​Sz​^​t/ℏ(2​1​∣+z⟩+2​1​∣−z⟩)=2​1​(eiω0​t/2⟨+z∣+e−iω0​t/2⟨−z∣)Sx​^​2​1​(e−iω0​t/2∣+z⟩+eiω0​t/2∣−z⟩)=21​(eiω0​t/2​e−iω0​t/2​)2ℏ​(01​10​)(e−iω0​t/2eiω0​t/2​)=2ℏ​21​(eiω0​t+e−iω0​t)=2ℏ​cos(ω0​t)​

which has a clear time-dependence.

Energy-Time Uncertainty

From the last post, we know from the the generalized uncertainty principle that

ΔAΔB≥12∣⟨[A^,B^]⟩∣\Delta A \Delta B \geq \frac {1}{2} |\langle \Big[ \hat A , \hat B \Big] \rangle|ΔAΔB≥21​∣⟨[A^,B^]⟩∣

For a time-independent operator A^\hat AA^, we have

ΔAΔE≥12⟨ψ∣[A^,H^]∣ψ⟩\Delta A \Delta E \geq \frac{1}{2} \langle\psi|\Big[\hat A, \hat H\Big]|\psi\rangleΔAΔE≥21​⟨ψ∣[A^,H^]∣ψ⟩

and from the time dependence of expectation,

d⟨A⟩dt=iℏ⟨ψ(t)∣[H^,A^]∣ψ(t)⟩\frac{d\langle A\rangle}{dt} = \frac{i}{\hbar} \langle\psi(t)| \Big[\hat H, \hat A \Big] |\psi(t)\rangledtd⟨A⟩​=ℏi​⟨ψ(t)∣[H^,A^]∣ψ(t)⟩

These two equations combined tell us that

ΔAΔE≥ℏ2∣d⟨A⟩dt∣ΔEΔA∣d⟨A⟩dt∣≥ℏ2ΔEΔt≥ℏ2\begin{aligned} \Delta A \Delta E &\geq \frac{\hbar}{2} |\frac{d\langle A\rangle}{dt}| \\ \Delta E \frac{\Delta A}{|\frac{d\langle A\rangle}{dt}|} &\geq \frac{\hbar}{2} \\ \Delta E \Delta t &\geq \frac{\hbar}{2} \end{aligned}ΔAΔEΔE∣dtd⟨A⟩​∣ΔA​ΔEΔt​≥2ℏ​∣dtd⟨A⟩​∣≥2ℏ​≥2ℏ​​

where Δt=ΔA∣d⟨A⟩dt∣\Delta t = \frac{\Delta A}{|\frac{d\langle A\rangle}{dt}|}Δt=∣dtd⟨A⟩​∣ΔA​ is the time for ⟨A⟩\langle A\rangle⟨A⟩ to change by ΔA\Delta AΔA.
